items.title: European ministers accuse Putin of feigning interest in peace talks
items.summary_auto: Ukraine and its European allies accused Russian President Vladimir Putin on Wednesday of feigning interest in peace efforts after five hours of talks with U.S. envoys at the Kremlin produced no breakthrough.

items.title: Canada pledges more than $200M in funding for Ukraine at NATO meeting
items.summary_auto: Canada has announced a second contribution to the the Prioritized Ukraine Requirements List (PURL) fund of more than $200 million. The mechanism was established by NATO to buy U.S.-made weapons after President Donald Trump said he was no longer interested in donating military equipment to Ukraine.

items.title: Israel says remains handed over by Hamas aren't those of Gaza hostage
items.summary_auto: Hamas said it would hand over a hostage body on Wednesday, after Israeli forensic services concluded that remains returned a day earlier were not from one of two final deceased hostages.

items.title: Deep-sea search for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 to resume
items.summary_auto: Malaysia's transport ministry said Wednesday that the deep-sea hunt for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370 will resume Dec. 30, renewing hopes of finally locating the jet that vanished without a trace more than a decade ago.

items.title: Burlington, Ont., couple joked about being brothers' jailers in text messages shown at murder trial
items.summary_auto: The first-degree murder trial of Brandy Cooney and Becky Hamber in Milton, Ont., heard more audio recordings of the couple berating the brothers in their care, and viewed more texts in which the two demeaned the brothers before the death of the eldest boy in 2022.

items.title: New data shows RSV shots prevent ‘most dangerous’ respiratory infection for newborns
items.summary_auto: Respiratory syncytial virus, or RSV, has long been the leading cause of infant hospitalization in Canada. While real-world studies show new RSV shots are working to keep newborns out of hospital, many Canadian families still don't have access to these groundbreaking tools.

items.title: As millions of Americans face pricier health insurance, is 'Trumpcare' the solution?
items.summary_auto: Health insurance is about to get a lot more expensive for millions of Americans, and that's posing a political challenge for U.S. President Donald Trump.

items.title: National Guard shooting and the CIA’s secret Afghan army
items.summary_auto: Who are the Zero Units, the secretive CIA-backed Afghan fighter group the alleged Washington National Guard shooter was a part of?

items.title: CFIA staff won't do interviews as avian flu outbreak in Ontario grows, citing death threats since ostrich cull
items.summary_auto: As the number of birds culled due to an avian flu outbreak on turkey farms near Strathroy, Ont., approaches 100,000, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency says they won't provide staff for media interviews for fear they will be subject of harassment, or death threats.

items.title: Montreal bike shop helps unhoused people switch gears, find work
items.summary_auto: Tri-Cycle’s project manager hopes the bike shop can be a springboard into the workforce for people experiencing homelessness or housing instability despite gaps in their resumés.

items.title: New study suggests urban raccoons are becoming more domesticated. Could they be pets one day?
items.summary_auto: In a new study, scientists discovered that raccoons who live in the city have shorter snouts, suggesting that they're moving toward domestication.

items.title: Ontario spent record $112M on taxpayer-funded advertising, auditor finds
items.summary_auto: Ontario spent a record $112 million on tax-payer-funded advertising last year, with the province’s auditor saying nearly 40 per cent of the campaigns could have left a “favourable impression” of Premier Doug Ford’s government ahead of the snap election.

items.title: Feds gave Stellantis more than $220M before Brampton decision, records show
items.summary_auto: The federal government paid Stellantis more than $220 million to help upgrade its plants in Ontario before the automaker revealed plans to move some production to the U.S., recent records show.

items.title: Why Canada's food inspection agency won't do interviews as avian flu outbreak in Ontario grows
items.summary_auto: As the number of birds culled due to an avian flu outbreak on turkey farms near Strathroy, Ont., approaches 100,000, the Canadian Food Inspection Agency says they won't provide staff for media interviews for fear they will be subject of harassment, or death threats.

items.title: The inside story of the $13M Mercedes linked to Ryan Wedding and seized by the FBI
items.summary_auto: CBC News has learned new details about the purchase last year of a rare Mercedes-Benz supercar, recently seized by the FBI amid its investigation into Canadian fugitive Ryan Wedding. The 2002 CLK-GTR Roadster was acquired for $11.9 million US by Wedding's alleged money launderer.

items.title: Edmonton Police Service partners with U.S. company to test use of facial-recognition bodycams
items.summary_auto: The Edmonton Police Service will test the use of bodycams that employ facial recognition, a form of artificial intelligence. Starting Wednesday, up to 50 police officers will use the cameras for the remainder of the month. However some academics warn that the technology is still not well-understood or reliable.

items.title: ICE ordering fleet of 20 armoured vehicles from Brampton, Ont., firm
items.summary_auto: U.S. Immigration and Customs Enforcement earmarked millions of dollars for a bulk order for 20 armoured vehicles from Canadian defence manufacturer Roshel that are built to resist bullets and bomb blasts.

items.title: B.C. to require witnesses for those who are prescribed safer supply of drugs
items.summary_auto: British Columbia's overdose-prevention safer supply program will require a witness when a user takes their drugs.

items.title: Trump administration pauses all immigration applications from 19 non-European countries
items.summary_auto: The Trump administration on Tuesday said it paused all immigration applications, including green  card and U.S. citizenship processing, filed by immigrants from 19 non-European countries, citing concerns over national security and public safety.

items.title: Algoma Steel is cutting 1,000 jobs. So why did it receive millions in government loans?
items.summary_auto: Just over two months after it was announced Algoma Steel would receive $500 million in government loan guarantees, the steel producer said it was issuing 1,000 layoff notices to workers at its plant in Sault Ste. Marie, Ont. The layoffs raise questions as to why it was receiving millions of dollars yet still cutting jobs.

items.title: Trump says National Guard will soon go to New Orleans
items.summary_auto: U.S. President Donald Trump said Tuesday that National Guard troops will soon head to New Orleans, bringing another federal surge to the city that is already awaiting a separate immigration crackdown expected to begin this week.

items.title: Will a fishing boat spark a crisis between China and Japan? | About That
items.summary_auto: Tensions between China and Japan are rising over Japanese Prime Minister Sanae Takaichi's recent comments on Taiwan, combined with a long-standing dispute over a chain of uninhabited islands. Andrew Chang breaks down why these tiny islands are so valuable, how Taiwan factors in and how this dispute has pushed two of Asia's biggest powers to a tipping point. Images provided by The Canadian Press, Reuters and Getty Images

items.title: Legault calls federal culture minister a 'disgrace to all Quebecers' for his comments on French language
Costco joins other companies in legal fight to demand refund of Trump tariffs
items.summary_auto: Costco has added its voice and heft to a lawsuit against the U.S. government seeking to ensure they will be reimbursed for tariffs they've been forced to pay if the U.S. Supreme Court rejects Donald Trump's assertion that he has sweeping authority to impose tariffs.

items.title: Unpacking the controversy over the notwithstanding clause
items.summary_auto: The notwithstanding clause has been part of Canadian law since 1982. So why is it now so controversial that it’s heading to the Supreme Court?

items.title: Ontario man raises $50K for cancer research on bike trip around world in honour of late wife
items.summary_auto: An Ontario man has cycled 30,000 kilometres around the world to raise money for cancer research in honour of his late wife.

items.title: 69-year-old bikes around the world to honour late wife, raise money for cancer research
items.summary_auto: The ruling released Tuesday from Justice Ward Branch says there's "some basis in fact" to support the plaintiffs' allegations that the "horrific fire" was caused by railway operations, where CN and CP have parallel tracks that run through the town.

items.title: Doctor behind Fraser Health whistleblower suit announces settlement
items.summary_auto: Emergency room physician Kaitlin Stockton says she has reached a settlement with the Fraser Health Authority to resolve a lawsuit that alleged wrongful dismissal after she tried to warn patients about conditions in two hospitals where she worked.

items.title: Sabrina Carpenter condemns Trump administration's use of lyrics after Franklin the turtle backlash
items.summary_auto: Pop singer Sabrina Carpenter and the publisher of the beloved children's character Franklin the Turtle are disavowing the Trump administration's use of their music and imagery to support its agenda.

items.title: Italian fashion group Prada buys rival Versace
items.summary_auto: The Prada Group closed the purchase of Milan fashion rival Versace in a $1.375 billion US ($1.93 billion Cdn) cash deal that puts the fashion house known for its sexy silhouettes under the same roof as Prada's "ugly chic" aesthetic and Miu Miu's youth-driven appeal.

items.title: Sean (Diddy) Combs calls Netflix docuseries, in which jurors explain verdict, a 'shameful hit piece'
items.summary_auto: Netflix has released a four-part docuseries about the criminal investigation and conviction of Sean (Diddy) Combs, despite the music mogul's lawyers accusing Netflix of using "stolen footage that was never authorized for release."

items.title: Israel says remains taken for forensic testing after Hamas handover
items.summary_auto: Hamas on Tuesday handed over the remains of one of the last two deceased hostages still in Gaza, the International Committee of the Red Cross said, under terms of the October ceasefire deal.
